subject: What should I be testing?
msgSnippet: I ve been playing a bit with Test Driven Development, and have read the book, but now I want to try it out, and am really not sure what to do next... My wife

Subject: What should I be testing?

I've been playing a bit with Test Driven Development, and have read the boo=
k, but now I want to try it out, and am really not sure what to do next...
=

My wife loves to show photo slide shows on our living room windows-XP comp=
uter (have patience, it will come together), but she doesn't like that the =
pictures show up in order.  I want to write a small utility to rename the p=
ictures in a controllable way, but prefixing something like 
"RND", a set o=
f random digits, and the original name.  For example, if the original was D=
CIM1001.jpg, I want the class to rename the file to "RND4356332_DCIM1001.jp=
g".  Windows can then show the photos in a 'random' order, but I can still =
figure out the real photo name, in case someone wants a copy.  Sounds simpl=
e.

I want to build this, using TDD.
I figure that I need to build tests, a=
nd get green bars in eclipse in the following order:
-instantiate my photoR=
andomizer class
-pass it several different paths, and have them be validate=
d (null, empty, non-existing, very long, very short, etc...).

that was eas=
y.
but my next question, is now what?
If I was writing this without TDD, my=
 next step, would have been to iterate through the directory, and rename al=
l of the files according to my scheme.  I can't see an operational advantag=
e to exposing any of this to outside, or make it more than one method, for =
testing purposes.

maybe what I should do, is have a method that iterates t=
hrough the appropriate directory, generates a random number, and then passe=
s both pieces of information to another method which renames the target fil=
e.  This doesn't seem like a very good way to do it, but then I would at le=
ast be able to test the renaming.

What am I missing?
